answers.answer: The answer is yes.  Use of corticosteroids (as opposed to anabolic steroids - a whole different topic) can raise total cholesterol, LDH, triglycerides and HDL.  this effect would return to normal after the steroids are stopped, but I couldn't find out how fast.How much the lipids are affected depend on the type of steroid, its dose and the method by which it is given.  Since we get MASSIVE doses IV you can see large changes in our lipid profiles.  The lowest changes are seen with inhaled steroids and ones that are given intermittently and in low dose (which wouldn't help us).Other common short term side effects in the body include lowering glucose-tolerance, so that it acts like a diabetes-enhancing drug, elevations of blood pressure, mood changes, changes in calcium metabolism, appetite enhancement, sleep disruption, anxiety, sa;t retention and swelling - and on-and-on.Quix
